div1.p: McClure writes of the prospects for the post-war economic situation, as well as rebuilding his house.

div1.head:
McClure & Stoner
Publishers
Franklin Repository Office,
Chambersburg, Pa.
div1.p: I wrote you last evening that I had arranged for my Lumber. A friend who is an old dealer, has kindly consented to supply me at cost, and I will save much trouble & some money by the arrangement.

i fully agree with you about the wisdom of Bains very high. was 22 1/2, & the new one will be the same. I would have made it 24, but for the fact that it will, at 22 1/2, be rather too prominent for the House.

I am going to rebuild my house this summer also & it is a fearful undertaking. I am sorely perplected about it & the more I study the more I get confused as to what kind of House I shall build. Mrs McC & I have agreed that the roof shall be on the top & the cellar under the House, but that is about as far as we have got.

My grounds are such that I have but a certain amount of room each way, without interfering with some tree or something else, so that I must locate it about as the old one was & cannot widen
out either way. I mean to follow the general plan of yours which is something after the old one, Library, Drawingroom, kitchen & on one side & parlor on the other.
I will go down to Philadelphia next week, if I can then meet Jr Rice & will stay there until I worry out a plan, & then I will dismiss the subject & put the contractor at work.
It is a jolly time to build. Home & Bain will cost me all of $20,000 & then finishing is to follow.

I think the war is ended, & the Order is safe. In that there is no army in Vgnia for to
fall back upon, they will soon be compelled to abandon their occupation, as the will be hunted & shot down wherever caught.
There will be restagnation in answer this year. Gold will higher. to 1866 than now, & I doubt a letter at will at any time in the next three years touch so long a as it did on Monday last.
Our debt is now $4,000,000,000. It is all very well as long as the gvnmnt delivers $4,000,000 per day: but when that stops, the severe ordeal for government credit will be at
